facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 29 of 1955 in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 29 of 1955. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 14th March, 1953, of the Bombay High Court in Income-Tax Reference No. 27 of 1952.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 14th March, 1953, of the Bombay High Court in Income-Tax Reference No. 27 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 14th March, 1953, of the Bombay High Court in Income-Tax Reference No. 27 of 1952. K. Daphtary, Solicitor-General of India, G. N.Joshi and H. Dhebar, for the appellant.

facts.text: The assessee is a non-resident company which has its head office in London and branches in India.

anchor.surface_text: Very briefly put, the relevant facts are these. The assessee, respondent before us, is a non-resident company which has its head office in London and branches in India. It sells and publishes books and magazines in various parts of the world.

facts.text: The assessee sells and publishes books and magazines in various parts of the world.

anchor.surface_text: It sells and publishes books and magazines in various parts of the world. For the assessment year in question, it submitted a return of income in which with regard to all publications sold in India, whether printed in India or elsewhere, a fixed percentage of what was known as the marked price was adopted as the cost of production.

facts.text: For the assessment year in question, the assessee submitted a return using a fixed percentage of the marked price as the cost of production for all publications sold in India.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year in question, it submitted a return of income in which with regard to all publications sold in India, whether printed in India or elsewhere, a fixed percentage of what was known as the marked price was adopted as the cost of production. This, if one may so put it, was the method of accounting on which the assessee company submitted its return.

facts.text: The Income-tax Officer accepted the assessee's method of accounting and assessed the assessee on an income of Rs. 82,623.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer apparently accepted it and subject to certain minor modifications as respects some items of expenditure and an alleged bad debt with which we are not concerned, assessed the assessee on an income of Rs. 82,623.

facts.text: The assessee appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner. The latter issued a notice under s. 31(3) of the Act against the assessee, and after hearing the assessee, enhanced the assessment of the assessee company's business income to Rs. 1,11,616.

facts.text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner enhanced the assessment to Rs. 1,11,616.

anchor.surface_text: enhanced the assessment of the assessee company's business income to Rs. 1,11,616. The Appellate Assistant Commissioner found It is noticed that on total turnover of Rs. 16,01,973 for the previous year ending 30th May, 1943, the gross profit amounted to Rs. 4,09,360 working out to just about 25.5 per cent.

facts.text: Total turnover of Rs. 16,01,973 for the previous year ending 30th May, 1943, gross profit Rs. 4,09,360 (25.5%).

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner found It is noticed that on total turnover of Rs. 16,01,973 for the previous year ending 30th May, 1943, the gross profit amounted to Rs. 4,09,360 working out to just about 25.5 per cent. In the case of World profit and loss account I find that the gross profit earned was £231,070 on total sales of £628,000 working out to over 37 per cent.

facts.text: World profit and loss account: gross profit £231,070 on total sales £628,000 (over 37%).

anchor.surface_text: In the case of World profit and loss account I find that the gross profit earned was £231,070 on total sales of £628,000 working out to over 37 per cent. The difference in gross profit is so wide that some explanation had to be called for from the appellants, especially in view of the fact that the appellants do not maintain what should be called an Indian trading and profit and loss account on the same lines as the World trading and profit and loss account.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner fixed income on basis of net world profit applied to Indian business, arriving at Rs. 1,11,616.

anchor.surface_text: He fixed the income of the assessee company on the basis of the net world profit of the assessee on its world turnover, and applying that basis to its Indian business came to the conclusion that the income of the assessee was Rs. 1,11,616.

facts.text: The assessee appealed to the Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee company then appealed to the Appellate Tribunal. The Appellate Tribunal remanded the case to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, but before the remand could be decided came the decision of the Bombay High Court in K. F. Vakeel v. The Commissioner of Income-tax.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal remanded the case to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal remanded the case to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, but before the remand could be decided came the decision of the Bombay High Court in K. F. Vakeel v. The Commissioner of Income-tax 1 .

facts.text: Bombay High Court decision in K. F. Vakeel v. The Commissioner of Income-tax influenced the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: but before the remand could be decided came the decision of the Bombay High Court in K. F. Vakeel v. The Commissioner of Income-tax 1 . The Tribunal then held that in view of that decision, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner had no jurisdiction to enhance the income to Rs. 1,11,616.

facts.text: Tribunal held Appellate Assistant Commissioner had no jurisdiction to enhance to Rs. 1,11,616.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal then held that in view of that decision, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner had no jurisdiction to enhance the income to Rs. 1,11,616. Thereafter, the Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City, appellant before us, asked the Tribunal to submit certain questions of law to the High Court of Bombay.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax asked Tribunal to refer questions to Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City, appellant before us, asked the Tribunal to submit certain questions of law to the High Court of Bombay. These questions were Whether it is open to an Appellate Assistant Commissioner on appeal to reject the assessees books of account, which have been accepted by the Income.

facts.text: Bombay High Court by judgment dated March 4, 1953 answered first two questions in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: By its judgment and order dated March 4, 1953, the High Court answered the first two questions in the negative and held-rightly in our view-that the third question did not arise.

facts.text: Appellant obtained special leave to appeal from Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then asked for and obtained special leave to appeal from the said judgment and order of the Bombay High Court.

facts.text: Assessment year 1944-45, year of account ended April 30, 1943.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1944-45 the respondent was assessed under the Act as a non-resident company. Its year of account ended on April 30, 1943.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer assessment order dated March 24, 1945, income Rs. 82,623.

anchor.surface_text: By his assessment order dated March 24, 1945, the Income tax Officer accepted the method of accounting employed by the respondent and its books of account for the Indian business. He,, however, added back certain items of expenses shown in the respondents balance-sheet and profit and loss account and computed the income at Rs. 82,623

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner order dated November 10, 1948, enhanced income by Rs. 1,11,616.

anchor.surface_text: After hearing the respondent the Appellate Assistant Commissioner made an order dated November 10, 1948, calculating the Indian business profits of the respondent on an amount which bore the same proportion to the net world profits of the respondents business as the Indian turnover bore to the world turnover and enhanced the Indian business income of the respondent by Rs. 1,11,616.

facts.text: Tribunal order dated April 29, 1950, remanded the case.

anchor.surface_text: By its order dated April 29, 1950, the Tribunal remanded the case to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner with a direction that he should allow the respondent to prove the actual cost of the goods invoiced to and sold in India.

facts.text: Tribunal allowed the appeal on October 16, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: the Tribunal accepted these contentions of the respondent and by its order dated October 16, 1951, allowed the appeal.

facts.text: Head office and branches outside India invoice publications to Indian branches at 25% of marked price for sterling publications and 30% for currency publications.

anchor.surface_text: The Head Office and branches outside India invoice publications to the Indian branches not at cost but at a valuation which is 25% of the marked price for sterling publications and 30% of the marked price for currency publications

facts.text: Respondent took invoice value as cost of publications in return for assessment year 1944-45.

anchor.surface_text: For the purposes of computing the profits of its Indian branches, the respondent takes the said valuation as the cost of the publications. For the assessment year 1944-45 the respondent was assessed under the Act as a non-resident company.

holdings.text: It is open to an Appellate Assistant Commissioner on appeal to reject the assessee's method of accounting under the proviso to s. 13 even if accepted by the Income-tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we would answer question No. 1 in the affirmative. As to question No. 2, only a few words are necessary. Rule 33 of the Indian Income-tax Rules, 1922, is in these terms In any case in which the Income-tax Officer is of opinion

holdings.reasoning_summary: AAC is revising authority with wide powers under s.31 to review every process of assessment including method of accounting; proviso to s.13 imposes no limitation; harmonious reading of ss.13 and 31; precedents like Narrondas support.

holdings.text: It is open to an Appellate Assistant Commissioner on appeal to invoke Rule 33 even if Income-tax Officer did not.

anchor.surface_text: For the same reasons which we have given with regard to question No. 1, the answer to question No. 2 is also in the affirmative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Same reasoning as Q1; Rule 33 uses similar language 'in the opinion of the Income-tax Officer' but AAC powers under s.31 allow it on appeal.

holdings.text: The proviso to s. 13 imposes no limitation on the powers of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner under s. 31.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the argument that the proviso to s. 13 imposes a limitation on the powers of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner under s. 31. No doubt, the two sections must be read harmoniously

holdings.reasoning_summary: Language of s.31 wide; no words of limitation in proviso; read harmoniously; AAC revises every process to assessment.

holdings.text: The determination of the Income-tax Officer under the proviso to s. 13 is not final and can be reviewed by AAC on appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Ancillary to the aforesaid two main contentions, there is a further divergence of opinion as to whether the determination of the Income-tax Officer under the proviso to s. 13, in so far as such determination depends on his opinion, is final or not.

holdings.reasoning_summary: AAC can interfere whether ITO decision for or against assessee; no distinction between subjective/objective; s.33B shows not final; precedents allow review.

holdings.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner can exercise power under proviso to s.13 to reject method of accounting for first time on assessee's appeal.

anchor.surface_text: the first question really means this is it open to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, on an appeal preferred by the assessee, to reject for the first time the method of accounting, purporting to act under the proviso to s. 13 of the Act,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Once appeal filed, whole assessment at large; AAC can correct ITO errors or omissions; no exclusive jurisdiction in ITO.

holdings.text: Reasons in K.F. Vakeel case on first ground incorrect; appellate authority can form opinion on proviso applicability.

anchor.surface_text: While, therefore, the actual decision in the case was undoubtedly correct, we are unable to accept as correct the following further observations in connection with the first ground But it is for the Income-tax Officer,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Actual decision correct on no material, but general proposition that only ITO can form opinion wrong; appellate can if seised.

holdings.text: The appeal is allowed; High Court answers set aside; questions 1 and 2 answered in affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal must, therefore, be allowed the judgment and order of the High Court of Bombay dated March 4, 1953, is set aside and the two questions referred to the said High Court are answered in favour of the Revenue.

holdings.text: Bhagwati J. (dissent): Power under proviso to s.13 cannot be exercised by AAC if ITO had not done so.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal ... raises an interesting question as to whether the power under the proviso to s. 13 of the Indian Income-tax Act ... can be exercised by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner while hearing an appeal of the assessee under s. 31 of the Act,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exclusive to ITO as named authority; condition precedent; appellate cannot substitute first opinion; Sarangpur remands to ITO.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal must, therefore, be allowed the judgment and order of the High Court of Bombay dated March 4, 1953, is set aside and the two questions referred to the said High Court are answered in favour of the Revenue. In view of the difficulty of interpretation and the divergence of opinion as respects the questions of law involved, we think that the parties must bear their own costs throughout.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; judgment and order of Bombay High Court dated March 4, 1953 set aside; two questions answered in favour of the Revenue (appellant)
directions: Parties to bear their own costs throughout

edges.explanation: Argument a10 notes Vakeel case reasons on exclusive ITO power incorrect, supporting h1 on AAC power.
Argument AAC cannot use proviso first rebuts holding
Argument limits power to ITO rebuts AAC exercising proviso
Argument that power exclusive to ITO supports dissent holding
Argument on ITO-exclusive power addresses finality issue
Argument denies AAC first-time power rebuts holding
Argument no AAC first-time rejection supports dissent
Argument distinguishes proviso power under s.13
Argument based on language of proviso to s.13
Argument interprets vesting of power in proviso to s.13
Holding interprets and applies proviso to s.13 allowing AAC rejection
Holding determines proviso to s.13 imposes no limit on AAC s.31 powers
Holding reviews ITO determination under proviso to s.13
Holding applies proviso to s.13 for AAC first-time rejection
Dissent interprets proviso to s.13 as limiting power to ITO
Broad appellate powers in c2 (s.31) support h1 allowing AAC to reject accounting method independently.
Holding h3 explicitly states that proviso to s.13 imposes no limitation on powers under s.31, directly grounded in the empowering provision c2.
Concept c3 (Rule 33) supports the holding h2 that invocation is open to Appellate Assistant Commissioner.
Concept c3 (Rule 33) is the provision whose invocability on appeal is questioned in issue i2.
